Grant Description: The program goal is to strengthen the capacity of community foundations in Europe to contribute to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. To this end, the Academy for the Development of Philanthropy in Poland will provide tailor-made grantmaking and technical assistance programs to community foundations in Europe to stimulate innovation in identifying and implementing local responses to global challenges. The grantee will develop a series of learning materials to support community foundations in their work on the global goals. Additionally, this grant increase will allow the grantee to help European community foundations address the current pressing challenges related to Ukrainian refugees in Europe following Russia’s military assault on Ukraine. To this end, the grantee will provide small grants to community foundations in European host countries for a wide range of refugee-related activities, including purchase and distribution of humanitarian aid, volunteer recruitment and training, and integration and adaptation services for people arriving from Ukraine.

The project goal is to support Ukrainian community foundations as they respond to critical humanitarian needs that have arisen as a result of Russia's war on Ukraine. Established in 1999, Ednannia is a recognized indigenous grantmaker, well regarded for its rigorous, transparent, responsive and effective processes to support community-level, grassroots organizations throughout Ukraine. Ednannia has supported community foundation development in Ukraine since 2009 through technical assistance, information, education and regranting. Ednannia will provide grants to up to 18 Ukrainian community foundations in order to ensure that they can effectively respond to the needs of their communities, internally displaced persons, donors and volunteers. They will also support local authorities in establishing shelters for the displaced, coordinate logistics of humanitarian support deliveries and collect funds for their communities. In addition to managing the regranting process, Ednannia will continue to provide informational and organizational development support to the community foundations.

The program goal is to provide comprehensive support to internally displaced persons and others affected by war in Ukraine. Through a network of online and offline legal advice centers, Gorenie will provide primary and secondary legal assistance to displaced victims of war in four regions (Dnipropetrovsk, Zaporizhiye, Kharkov and Ukraine-controlled Donetsk) bordering on the war zone that has received the bulk of such migrants. The grantee will provide training services for local officials to improve service delivery and integration practices related to target groups. The grantee will also work to build the self-organizing capacity of these target groups. From 2018-2020, the grantee provided primary and secondary legal assistance to over 50,000 Ukrainians directly impacted by war. Over 160,000 requests for legal and social benefit information were processed through Gorenie's mobile legal assistance app. Based in Dnipro, Gorenie was founded in 2005 to provide wide-ranging assistance to disadvantaged and marginalized groups throughout Ukraine. This increase will allow Gorenie to update and improve legal and rights information for displaced persons, ensure security of staff, and open additional premises where people can find support and assistance under conditions of evacuation and martial law.

The program goal is to increase community-based access to justice for the Ukrainian public. The Legal Development Network will work to strengthen and expand the current network of 30 community legal centers in Ukraine. Continuing attention will be given to equipping centers with skills and capacity to work with local authorities in providing access to justice. The grantee will also seek to integrate the network into international partnerships to further build capabilities of members. In 2019-2021, the grantee conducted 11 legal needs surveys in different regions of Ukraine, resulting in six access to justice programs in participating communities. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, network members nearly doubled the number of clients served in 2020, compared to the previous year. Working with Ukrainian and international partners, the grantee also initiated widespread discussion on “people-centered justice” and how this can be achieved in Ukraine. This increase will allow the grantee to increase provision of legal services and help coordinate other assistance for people displaced following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Formally registered in 2015 and with its secretariat in Kyiv, the Legal Development Network has member organizations in 15 regions of Ukraine.

The European Programme for Integration and Migration is a donor collaborative hosted by the Network of European Foundations for Innovative Cooperation. Established in 2005, this program strengthens the role played by civil society organizations in advocating for constructive approaches to migration in Europe. This is done through grantmaking, capacity development and networking activities addressing a range of issues, including: asylum seekers; undocumented migrants; and equality, integration, and social inclusion of vulnerable migrants. Between 2005 and 2020, this program has: involved 36 European foundations in collaborative programming and grantmaking; leveraged funding from these foundations; provided more than 20 million Euros to over 300 civil society organizations; and organized more than 70 pan-european exchange, training and networking events involving over 3,500 participants. Based in Brussels, the Network of European Foundations for Innovative Cooperation strengthens cooperation among foundations in Europe. This grant increase will contribute to a special fund assisting refugees in Europe following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

The program goal is to support the organizational and programmatic development of People in Need, one of the largest nonprofits in Central and Eastern Europe. Founded in 1992, the grantee: 1) provides relief and development assistance in response to natural disasters and violent conflict; 2) promotes human rights, civic engagement and civil society development; and 3) supports social inclusion and integration for marginalized groups. During the grant period, the grantee will continue to respond to crises arising from war and conflict, natural disasters and the COVID-19 pandemic through its humanitarian relief programs and its support to civil society organizations working on education, human rights and social inclusion. Based in Prague, Czech Republic, grant increase will enable People in Need to respond to the humanitarian needs arising from the war in Ukraine and support the work of Ukrainian civil society organizations during the crisis.

In the face of the ongoing war in Ukraine, the Ukrainian Helsinki Human Rights Union will use additional funds for several purposes. These include: securing a level of protection to its employees, including life-saving relocation needs; expanding its network of public reception offices network to additional regions of Ukraine in order to increase citizens’ access to legal assistance; monitoring and documenting brutal human rights abuses and war crimes committed by Russia’s occupation forces in order to hold criminals accountable domestically and internationally; strengthening capacity of legal practitioners on documentation; and knowledge of international humanitarian law and applicable human rights law.

The Ukrainian Legal Aid Foundation will work closely with the coordinating center for Legal Aid of the Ministry of Justice to enhance skills and training of paralegals to increase assistance to Ukrainians experiencing consequences of Russia's invasion of their country. Paralegals will help coordinate humanitarian and legal assistance in conjunction with relevant government agencies and other civil society partners.

During the past grant period, the grantee provided 17 grants totaling more than $330,000 to community foundations in 12 countries to support their engagement with the global goals as well as 15 grants totaling over $280,000 to community foundations in eight countries supporting Ukrainian refugees. The grantee also published a series of learning materials and organized learning events to increase the capacity of European community foundations to contribute to the global goals. The grantee is based in Warsaw, Poland.

The program goal is to support access to justice in small communities in Ukraine through strengthening of local justice institutions. The Charity and Health Foundation will work with newly amalgamated communities in territories of southeast Ukraine to help expand practice and understanding of community-based policing, with a particular focus on improving juvenile justice practices. The grantee will also research, monitor and broadly publicize local experiences of how new models of community-based justice are improving lives of citizens and how they can positively inform wider law enforcement reforms. During 2019-2021, the grantee produced over 300 online and offline publications detailing community justice practices and highlighting deficiencies in juvenile justice provisions in rural communities. The grantee also produced further material on community policing for inclusion in the curriculum of Ukraine’s leading institution for police training. In the wake of Russia's illegal invasion of Ukraine, the grantee will gather and distribute information about successful community organizing aimed at providing community safety and accessible social and legal assistance.

This grant supports the Council on Foundations' Global Philanthropy Program, which is framed around four pillars of activity: (1) strengthening cross-border grantmaking, (2) advocating for a global enabling environment, (3) facilitating global convenings and conversations, and (4) developing global resources and thought leadership. With previous Mott support, the council has produced publications on responding globally to COVID-19, conducted webinars on various global topics of interest to its members, convened funders around India’s restrictions on foreign funding and updated members on regulatory changes that affect giving to organizations in selected countries. With this increase, the council will be able to host a peer learning circle for its members and other foundations in North America to support philanthropy's response to the crisis in Ukraine. This will be done in partnership with the German Marshall Fund, Community Foundations of Canada and Philanthropic Foundations of Canada.

The program goal is to improve reporting on, and documenting of, potential war crimes arising in Ukraine following Russia’s invasion of February 2022. To this end, the Global Investigative Journalism Network will update and expand its toolkit of issue and practice guides, tip sheets and trainings that assist journalists and correspondents to understand both the news value and the forensic needs of documenting evidence of a war crime. The toolkit will be translated into Ukrainian and Russian initially and will be distributed throughout the grantee’s network. This effort will be boosted by engagement of a Ukrainian-speaking editor able to respond quickly to requests from Ukrainian journalists for resources to document potential crimes. Founded in 2003, the Global Investigative Journalism Network has grown to include 227 member groups in 82 countries. It works to link together the world’s most enterprising journalists, giving them the tools, technology and training to uncover abuses of power and lack of accountability.

The program goal is to strengthen the practice of community paralegals in Ukraine. Such community-based paralegals have become increasingly important in providing legal, health, humanitarian and related information and services in the wake of Russia’s illegal invasion of Ukraine. Drawing on its growing pre-war experience in Ukraine and on extensive experience of paralegal development abroad, the Ukrainian Legal Aid Foundation will develop a series of specialized online training courses for these community justice actors. It will also work to develop mutually supportive networks of paralegals, community health care workers, civic advisors and others working to provide information and legal support to Ukrainians in order to supplement resources available from the state. In 2020-22, the grantee developed a comprehensive online training course for community paralegals with over 200 participants completing the course and a further 200 beginning the process. Over this time, paralegals dealt with over 10,000 enquiries on a range of legal issues affecting Ukrainians. The Ukrainian Legal Aid Foundation works to ensure access to justice in Ukraine through the support and provision of legal aid services and through improving the standards of justice provision.

Grant Description: The Foundation recently granted $150,000 to The Jewish Federation of Greater Los Angeles’ emergency relief fund to help those directly affected by the developing crisis in Ukraine. Grant Description: Responding to widespread power outages and preparing for what is projected to be a worsening humanitarian crisis this winter in Ukraine, Jewish Federations of North America are allocating $7 million for Ukraine aid, including a focus on emergency winter relief. Since the beginning of the war, 52,500 new immigrants have arrived in Israel from Russia, Ukraine and Belarus with the aid of Jewish Federations’ partner, The Jewish Agency for Israel.

Many of the refugees are women who left Ukraine to bring their children to safety while their husbands and fathers stayed back to work or to serve in the military. Slow Beskid will provide safe accommodation for the women and children they serve. Children's Paths' donation will help purchase a new bus to transport the children they service.  Suzanne Johnson, wife of Jets Chairman, Robert Wood Johnson, grew up in a Ukrainian neighborhood in New York and is from a family of immigrants.

The Nippon Foundation will provide 5.08 billion yen in financial assistance to Ukrainians evacuating to Japan. The money, to be disbursed over three years, is intended to cover their traveling and living costs. Of the total sum, 3.55 billion yen will be earmarked for traveling and living costs. Each evacuee will be eligible to receive 300,000 yen to cover travel expenses and 1 million yen annually for living expenses for three years. Each household would receive up to 3 million yen per year for living expenses. Local governments have already announced they will offer public housing to Ukrainian evacuees, so the foundation decided to provide 500,000 yen per household for purchases of home electronic appliances and other necessities. In addition, the foundation said it will give 1.53 billion yen to NPOs working to support the daily lives of Ukrainian evacuees in Japan.

The Stavros Niarchos Foundation (SNF) announced $1 million in emergency relief grants to six organizations to aid those affected by the war in Ukraine. Three of the grant recipients are providing direct aid on the ground in Ukraine and neighboring countries, including: (1) Doctors of the World Spain, which is supplying traumatology and surgical materials to 20 hospitals in Ukraine and where safety allows, continuing to provide primary, reproductive, and mental health care to those who are most vulnerable, including older adults, people with disabilities, and people who have been internally displaced; (2) Choose Love, which works with local grassroots organizations to aid vulnerable people on the move in Ukraine, Poland, Moldova, and Romania; and (3) Lumos Foundation, which has been providing emergency packages of food, hygiene items, and medical supplies to children and families in Odessa and the Zhytomyr region, supporting the safe relocation of children from institutions, providing packages and financial support to emergency foster parents, offering mental health “first aid,” and building capacity to help children access child protection, health, and education services. Another granteee, Melissa Network, is supporting Ukrainian refugees arriving in Greece, including by assisting existing Ukrainian networks in the country in offering a coordinated response, services to safeguard children’s resilience, psychosocial support for new arrivals and locals alike, help accessing employment, and legal services. Two additional grants are aimed at addressing the immediate threats the war poses to people around the world. This includes grants to: (1) Save the Children USA to address the global food emergency threatening to increase hunger and malnutrition for millions of children; and (2) Doctors Without Borders USA to ensure that people affected by “neglected” crises elsewhere in the world receive the health care they urgently need.

Grant Description: Western Union has provided €100,000 towards the direct purchase of blankets, first aid kits and portable phone chargers, supplies urgently needed by those who have been displaced by the war in Ukraine.

The Western Union Foundation announced its first donation of $100,000 to International Medical Corps, providing medical aid and supplies, mental health support and protection services to refugees from Ukraine who have fled to Poland, Moldova, and Romania.

In Lithuania, the local Western Union Foundation has committed €20,000 to Lietuvos Raudonasis Kryžius – also known as the Lithuanian Red Cross – to fund emergency supplies for those effected by the war in Ukraine.
White & Case has made a donation of US$1 million to the Ukrainian Red Cross Society.

Whole Planet Foundation is supporting Concern Worldwide with a $50,000 grant to provide food kits to internally displaced peoples (IDPs) in Ukraine who are living in shelters or hosted in private homes in Western Ukraine. The foods kits include items like pasta, buckwheat grain, water, canned fish, canned meat, tea, and high energy biscuits. WPF funds will cover food kits for an estimated 100 people per day at each of 12 distribution points, for a period of three months.
Title: In Ukraine, Whole Planet Foundation Is Supporting Entrepreneurs and Internally Displaced People
Author: Zoc So

Grant Description: To date, some $62 million has been raised by Jewish Federations of North America and its partners to provide assistance to those being impacted by the war in Ukraine, leaving a shortfall of $37 million. To help bridge the gap, the Wilf Family Foundations has pledged $5 million towards this next stage of funding for Ukraine aid.
Title: JFNA estimates aid to Ukraine projected at $100 million

Grant Description: The William Demant Foundation is providing funding to support humanitarian aid in and outside the Ukraine to meet the growing needs of children and families, including those on the move. It has allocated DKK 7 million ($1 million USD) to the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) which is scaling up emergency response across Ukraine and the wider region.
Title: William Demant Foundation to Donate $1.2M to Ukraine

Grant Description: The William Demant Foundation is providing funding to support humanitarian aid in and outside the Ukraine to meet the growing needs of children and families, including those on the move. The Foundation has designated DKK 1 million ($150,000 USD) for Demant employees to support the relief initiatives of established, officially recognized humanitarian organizations located predominately in the Ukraine and Poland.
Title: William Demant Foundation to Donate $1.2M to Ukraine

Grant Description: Wilson Sonsini Foundation will make a $50,000 contribution to three nonprofits already on the ground in Ukraine assisting in the relief efforts, including Save the Children US, Direct Relief, and World Central Kitchen. The donation will provide immediate aid in the form of food, water, shelter, and medical supplies. In addition to the fundraising campaign, the firm’s pro bono team plans to assist those in need of legal aid.
The Wilson Sonsini Foundation will match all employee donations to Save the Children US, Direct Relief, and World Central Kitchen up to $50,000.
The Wimbledon Foundation will be making a donation of £100,000 to the British Red Cross to support their Ukraine Crisis Appeal.
The Wimbledon Foundation will be donating £50,000 to the DEC’s Ukraine Humanitarian Appeal to help provide food, water, shelter, healthcare and protection to families fleeing the conflict.

Grant Description: Winston & Strawn is matching employee donations up to $25,000. Funds will be given to the International Committee of the Red Cross.
The Woodward Charitable Trust made a £6,000 donation to the British Red Cross for relief efforts in Ukraine.
The Woodward Charitable Trust made a £6,000 donation to Save the Children UK for relief efforts in Ukraine.

Recipient Name: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)
Grant Description: 50,000 CHF donation the United Nations Ukraine Humanitarian Fund from the non-profit organization representing the sporting goods industry.

Global nonprofit World Hope International (WHI) has partnered with first-aid supplies and training company My Medic™ to supply 3,000 first aid kits, valued at over $500,000 USD, to emergency first responders who are treating individuals injured as a result of the war in Ukraine.
Title: World Hope International Partners With My Medic™ to Donate $500,000 in Individual First Aid Kits to Ukrainian First Responders

Grant Description: $100,000 from Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions’ (WFCU) Ukrainian Credit Union Displacement Fund is providing targeted aid to farmers faced with an increasing food security crisis brought on by Russia’s war in Ukraine. Utilizing an account set up in collaboration with Ridynia, a Ukrainian NGO, the grant dollars from WFCU will go to reimburse at least 585 farmers on 10% of their agricultural loan principal payments.
Title: Ukraine Agricultural Loan Reimbursement Program Launches with $100,000 Grant from Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions

Grant Description: Cash donation to UNICEF National Committee Germany.
Title: Ukraine Private Sector Donations Tracker

Grant Description: Wyndham is donating $100,000 to support the humanitarian relief efforts of Save the Children, which is currently on the ground in Ukraine and neighboring countries.

XTX Markets donated £10mn to support the UN Refugee Agency, via the UK for UNHCR Ukraine Emergency appeal. This is to provide immediate protection and shelter to internally displaced people in Ukraine and refugees in neighbouring countries.

Yamaha Motor announced its decision to donate 700,000 U.S. dollars toward humanitarian aid for Ukraine and its surrounding regions. This donation will be made through Japan Platform, a non-profit organization, and the funds will be used explicitly for delivering humanitarian aid to those in need.
Yoshiki announced that he was donating ¥10,000,000 (approximately $86,000 USD) for humanitarian relief efforts in Ukraine via a fundraiser by Japanese e-commerce site Rakuten.
Title: X Japan’s Yoshiki Helps Raise Nearly $5 Million for Ukraine After Making His Own Major Donation
Author: Jon Hadusek

Grant Description: Yoshiki Hayashi, Japanese composer and leader of rock band X JAPAN, donated 10 million Japanese Yen to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) for its emergency relief operations in Ukraine and neighbouring countries.
Title: Japanese Artist Yoshiki Donates JPY 10 Million to IOM Ukraine Relief Efforts

Grant Description: Japanese composer YOSHIKI, leader of both X Japan, and the new international rock band THE LAST ROCKSTARS, announced that he is making a donation of 10 million yen to the International Organization for Migration (IOM), bringing the total amount he donated to IOM to 20 million yen. This donation will enable IOM to further support all those affected by the war in Ukraine and will directly support emergency relief operations in Ukraine and neighboring countries.
Title: Japan's Iconic Rock Star YOSHIKI Announces His Holiday Wish & Donation to Help All Refugees Affected by War in Ukraine

Recipient Name: International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)
Grant Description: The Yum! Brands Foundation is donating $1 million worth of profits from its Russian operations to humanitarian efforts. Yum Brands Foundation will be forwarding the fund to the Red Cross to support people affected by the ongoing crisis in Ukraine.

The Yuri and Julia Milner Foundation donated $2 million to Stand With Ukraine fundraiser organized by Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher on GoFundMe.org. The fund will benefit Flexport.org and Airbnb.org, two organizations who are actively on the ground providing immediate help to those who need it most. Flexport.org is organizing shipments of relief supplies to refugee sites in Poland, Romania, Hungary, Slovakia and Moldova. Airbnb.org is providing free, short-term housing to refugees fleeing Ukraine.
Nova Ukraine has received a $1 million donation from Zapier to support Ukrainian refugees and asylum seekers. This amount represents every dollar Zapier has made from Russian and Belarusian accounts.
Title: Nova Ukraine Receives $1M Donation from Zapier for Refugees in Ukraine
